fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S \triangleright P be a container. A mnd-container (or monad container) on S \triangleright P is given by the following data: \begin {align*} \iota &: S\\ \sigma &: \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to S) \to S\\ \text {pr} &: \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to S\}} P\ (\sigma \ s\ f) \to \sum _{p : P\ s} P\ (f\ p) \end {align*} For which the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a ) &= a\\ \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) &= a\\ \sigma \ (\sigma \ a\ f)\ (\lambda p . g\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\ (\text {pr}_2\ p)) &= \sigma \ a\ (\lambda p . \sigma \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_1\ p) &= \text {pr}_1\ p\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) \end {align*} We abbreviate \pi _1 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_1 and \pi _2 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_2. The last three laws hold up the "associativity" law for \sigma .

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad container. We call the monad container commutative when the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) &= \sigma \ b\ (\lambda \_ . a)\\ \text {pr}_1\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ p\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_1\ p \end {align*} The laws for \text {pr} hold given the first law. Commutative monad containers interpret exactly the commutative monads for container functors.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as Set functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating all possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
